args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (typically a funerary object or text) is designed, intended, or used to achieve the purpose, function, or outcome expressed by the object.
args.justification: All three relations link funerary objects or texts (religious texts, amulets) to the intended outcome they are meant to achieve (safe passage, eternal existence), i.e., an intentional purpose relation. They currently mix two close canonical predicates ('used_for' and 'has_purpose') and two similar classes ('funerary_object_function_relation' and 'funerary_purpose_relation'). Normalizing to a single predicate 'has_purpose' and a unified class 'funerary_object_purpose_relation' improves schema consistency while accurately capturing their shared semantics.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject (typically a funerary object or text) is designed, intended, or used to achieve the purpose, function, or outcome expressed by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations link funerary objects or texts (religious texts, amulets) to the intended outcome they are meant to achieve (safe passage, eternal existence), i.e., an intentional purpose relation. They currently mix two close canonical predicates ('used_for' and 'has_purpose') and two similar classes ('funerary_object_function_relation' and 'funerary_purpose_relation'). Normalizing to a single predicate 'has_purpose' and a unified class 'funerary_object_purpose_relation' improves schema consistency while accurately capturing their shared semantics.
